results.abstract: Liftoff of space shuttle Discovery and its seven astronauts is scheduled for July 1; 12-day mission will carry supplies to International Space Station, along with new crew member, Thomas Reiter of Germany; more important to future of space program is issue of flaws that doomed two previous missions; NASA Admr Michael D Griffin comments; diagrams; photos (M)

headline.main: Discovery's 'Pedestrian Mission' Means a Lot to NASA

results.snippet: The space shuttle Discovery and its seven astronauts are to roar into orbit on what NASA managers called "a rather pedestrian mission."

byline.original: By JOHN SCHWARTZ and WARREN E. LEARY

multimedia.caption: Audio & Photos: Taking Off, Again
multimedia.credit: The space shuttle Discovery was prepared for its launch from Cape Canaveral, Fla.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: The space shuttle Discovery was prepared for its launch from Cape Canaveral, Fla.

results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Discovery and its seven astronauts are to roar into orbit on Saturday afternoon on what NASA managers called ''a rather pedestrian mission'' that nevertheless has a great deal riding on it. Liftoff is scheduled for 3:49, when Earth's rotation will put the launching pad at the Kennedy Space Center here in the orbital plane of the International Space Station, the shuttle's destination.

headline.main: SHUTTLE MAKES A SAFE RETURN TO SPACEFLIGHT

results.snippet: The Discovery's ascent was intensely scrutinized for liftoff debris in the first flight in a year for NASA's shuttle fleet.

byline.original: By JOHN SCHWARTZ and WARREN E. LEARY

multimedia.caption: Slide Show: Discovery's Liftoff
multimedia.credit: The space shuttle Discovery successfully launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla., on Tuesday, July 4, at 2:38 p.m.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: The space shuttle Discovery successfully launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla., on Tuesday, July 4, at 2:38 p.m.

results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Discovery split a nearly cloudless sky with thunder and fire on Tuesday afternoon and roared safely into orbit. The liftoff, right on schedule at 2:38 p.m., was the start of a 13-day flight that is the first in a year for the diminished shuttle fleet as NASA continues its efforts to resume more frequent human spaceflight.

results.abstract: NASA officials express optimism that shuttle Discovery ascended to orbit with no damage and significantly less shedding of foam debris than in previous flights; astronauts begin their detailed inspection of spacecraft for possible damage; NASA official sounds note of caution and says more data will be collected and closer examination of craft will continue over next few days (M)

headline.main: NASA Aides Optimistic On Status Of Shuttle

results.snippet: So far, the shuttle Discovery appeared to have come through its ascent to orbit with no damage and less shedding of foam debris than in previous flights.

byline.original: By JOHN SCHWARTZ and WARREN E. LEARY; John Schwartz reported from Houston for this article, and Warren E. Leary from Florida

multimedia.caption: Slide Show: Discovery's Liftoff
multimedia.credit: The space shuttle Discovery successfully launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla., on Tuesday, July 4, at 2:38 p.m.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: The space shuttle Discovery successfully launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla., on Tuesday, July 4, at 2:38 p.m.

results.lead_paragraph: NASA engineers and managers expressed optimism Wednesday that the shuttle Discovery had come through its ascent to orbit with no damage and substantially less shedding of foam debris from the external tank than in previous flights. ''People are very excited that they have not been surprised by anything,'' said John Shannon, shuttle deputy program manager, after a briefing with reporters.

results.abstract: In this lesson, students consider the safety measures featured for various modes of transportation. They then create How It Works posters showcasing the safety devices on the space shuttle Discovery and reflect on how an equipment failure might affect a mission.

byline.original: By JENNIFER RITTNER and JAVAID KHAN

results.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Discovery docks with International Space Station; executes graceful back flip as it approaches station; maneuver is part of safety program to inspect underside of craft (M)

headline.main: Space Shuttle Does Back Flip And Rendezvous With Station

results.snippet: Crew members on the International Space Station took detailed photographs of the Discovery to look for damage.
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Discovery glided Thursday morning to a smooth rendezvous with the International Space Station. The approach, at a gradual one-tenth of a foot per second as both craft raced through orbit at 17,500 miles an hour, could be seen on NASA Television from a camera mounted in the Discovery's docking mechanism.

results.abstract: Discovery crew uses Italian-made cargo carrier to move thousands of pounds of supplies to International Space Station, as engineers on ground scrutinize images of space shuttle for damage that might cause problems in brutal heat of re-entry; photo (M)

headline.main: Seeking Signs Of Trouble, NASA Studies Shuttle Images

results.snippet: On a day devoted to moving thousands of pounds of supplies from the space shuttle Discovery to the International Space Station, engineers and analysts on the ground scrutinized images of the shuttle on Friday for damage that might cause problems in...
results.lead_paragraph: On a day devoted to moving thousands of pounds of supplies from the space shuttle Discovery to the International Space Station, engineers and analysts on the ground scrutinized images of the shuttle on Friday for damage that might cause problems in the brutal heat of re-entry. Officials said that the shuttle came through the rigors of ascent in a remarkably clean state and that they had narrowed their analysis to a few unresolved issues.

headline.main: In Paris, Only the Moat Was Missing

results.snippet: A review of the haute couture collections in Paris shows that Lagerfeld and Galliano go way, way back. This is a historic moment, indeed.

multimedia.caption: Slide Show: Freedom on the Runway
multimedia.credit: Looks from Dior, Galliano, Givenchy, Christian Lacroix and others.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Looks from Dior, Galliano, Givenchy, Christian Lacroix and others.
legacy.MultimediaHeadline1: Slide Show: Freedom on the Runway

results.lead_paragraph: ''BERNARD, Cher, s'il vous pla√Æt,'' the photographer cooed as Bernard Arnault, the luxury-goods king, and Cher snapped into a huddle. They were backstage at the Dior show to see John Galliano. Everyone, about 200 people, was trying to see Mr. Galliano, who had had the idea of ending his haute couture show of medieval clothes set in Botticelli's garden by coming out dressed as an astronaut. ''Yeah, it was a moment,'' the designer said with a self-mocking grin.

headline.main: Reporter's Notebook; New Scrutiny for Every Speck on the Shuttle

results.snippet: Tools developed since the Columbia disaster deliver stunningly clear images of the shuttle, and endless new problems for NASA to worry about.
results.lead_paragraph: Is the space shuttle Discovery safe to re-enter the atmosphere on its way to landing next Monday? Determining that it is, as the National Aeronautics and Space Administration did on Sunday, is an arduous process. Even though engineers and analysts say there is really no choice for an agency still climbing back from a horrendous re-entry accident -- the loss of the shuttle Columbia and its crew of seven on a bright February morning in 2003 -- the level of detail can sometimes seem absurd.

results.abstract: Astronauts aboard space shuttle discovery continue to move supplies into International Space Station, take telephone call from Pres Bush and prepare for third and final spacewalk; Anthony J Ceccacci, flight director, says shuttle appears to have come through launching with little or no damage (M)

headline.main: Astronauts, Happy About Mission, Prepare for 3rd Spacewalk

results.snippet: The crew of the space shuttle Discovery continued to move supplies into the International Space Station and fielded a phone call from President Bush.
results.lead_paragraph: Astronauts aboard the space shuttle Discovery continued to move supplies into the International Space Station on Tuesday while fielding a phone call from President Bush and preparing for their third and final spacewalk. Crews of the shuttle and the space station received a late morning private call from Mr. Bush, who said he had seen part of a Monday spacewalk in which the astronauts repaired a remote-controlled sled that crosses rails atop the station, and wanted to thank them for their service to the country. He also invited the Discovery crew and their families to visit the White House after the mission, a White House spokesman said.

results.snippet: The space shuttle Discovery detached from the International Space Station early Saturday, slipping away from the research outpost after more than a week of joint operations that set the stage for future missions.     Following photographs and...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Discovery detached from the International Space Station early Saturday, slipping away from the research outpost after more than a week of joint operations that set the stage for future missions. Following photographs and farewells, the six-member Discovery crew and three astronauts remaining on the station closed hatches and made final checks before the shuttle undocked at 6:08 a.m. EDT and slowly pulled away.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Discovery detaches from International Space Station after more than a week of joint operations; stayed within sight of space station while shuttle crew completed final round of inspections to make sure its heat shield was intact; only remaining concern about Discovery's mission is slight fuel leak in one of three auxiliary power units; photo (M)

headline.main: Its Job Done, Shuttle Leaves Space Station

results.snippet: After photographs and farewells, the six-member Discovery crew and three astronauts remaining on the station closed hatches and made final checks before the shuttle undocked.
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Discovery detached from the International Space Station early Saturday, slipping away from the research outpost after more than a week of joint operations that set the stage for future missions. After photographs and farewells, the six-member Discovery crew and three astronauts remaining on the station closed hatches and made final checks before the shuttle undocked at 6:08 a.m., Eastern time, and slowly pulled away.

results.abstract: Motorcycle accidents and fatalities rise in California; number of motorcyclists has increased because of soaring fuel costs and congested freeways, and their inexperience threatens themselves and other motorcyclists; another factor is advent of very fast, very maneuverable high performance motorcycles requiring high level of skill; photos (M)
results.snippet: Lately, motorcycle riding has lost some of its carefree personality, even in California, the setting for the events that inspired “The Wild One.”
results.lead_paragraph: A MOTORCYCLE has never been for the faint of heart -- free spirits of all sorts have long exulted in their ability to breathe fresh air outside the ''cage'' of a car while weaving in and out of stalled traffic, or zipping around the hairpin turns of a mountain road. But lately, motorcycle riding has lost some of its carefree personality, even in California, the setting for the events that inspired ''The Wild One,'' for Steve McQueen's off-road adventures and for much of the restless spirit of motorcycle culture. Motorcycle sales in the state have jumped about 40 percent since 2001, spurred partly by drivers seeking relief from rising fuel costs and congested freeways. All those newbie riders -- many of them revving a new generation of more powerful bikes -- combined with more challenging road conditions have contributed to a significant rise in accidents. Easy Rider isn't sitting so easy anymore.

headline.main: After Passing Tests for Damage, Shuttle Is Cleared to Return Home

results.snippet: Discovery has two opportunities about 90 minutes apart to land at the Kennedy Space Center on Monday.
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Discovery is coming home, buoyed by positive tests and inspections indicating that it is in good shape for a landing in Florida on Monday, after a 13-day mission to the International Space Station. ''The vehicle has been totally cleared for entry,'' the lead flight director, Steven Stich, said Sunday.

headline.main: All Smiles as Shuttle Ends A Nearly Perfect Mission

results.snippet: The morale boost of a successful flight after the loss of the shuttle Columbia and a frustrating test flight last year was evident on the faces of the crew and NASA officials.

byline.original: By JOHN SCHWARTZ; Warren E. Leary contributed reporting from Houston for this article, and John Files from Washington

multimedia.caption: Slide Show: The Shuttle Lands Safely
multimedia.credit: Discovery ended a 13-day mission that paved the way for completion of the space station.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Discovery ended a 13-day mission that paved the way for completion of the space station.
legacy.MultimediaHeadline1: Slide Show: The Shuttle Lands Safely

results.lead_paragraph: With a distinctive double sonic boom and a whooshing glide to the ground, the space shuttle Discovery landed safely Monday morning, ending a nearly flawless 13-day mission. ''Welcome back, Discovery,'' Stephen N. Frick, a NASA astronaut communicating with the shuttle from mission control in Houston, said to the shuttle commander, Col. Steven W. Lindsey of the Air Force, after the shuttle had come to a halt.

headline.main: Walk in Space For $15 Million (Plus Airfare)

results.snippet: Space Adventures Ltd., the company that sent the first tourists to space, is about to start offering its clients an alluring add-on: a spacewalk.
results.lead_paragraph: The company that sent the first tourists to space is about to start offering its clients an alluring add-on: a spacewalk. Space Adventures Ltd., a company based in Vienna, Va., that has sent three very wealthy men to orbit the earth on the International Space Station, is planning to announce today that future customers will be able to take an hour-and-a-half trip outside the station as well.

results.abstract: Charles E Brady Jr, former space shuttle astronaut and amateur radio enthusiast, dies at age 54 (M)

headline.main: Charles Brady Jr., 54, Astronaut And a Ham Radio Enthusiast

results.snippet: Charles E. Brady was one of the first operators of the Shuttle Amateur Radio Experiment, or Sarex, which allowed astronauts to talk with ham radio operators around the world.
results.lead_paragraph: Charles E. Brady Jr., a former space shuttle astronaut and amateur radio enthusiast, died July 23 at his home in Oak Harbor, Wash., the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has reported. He was 54. A cause of death was not given, but an obituary published on the Web site of the American Radio Relay League said Dr. Brady, a former flight surgeon and captain in the Navy, had died after a lengthy illness.
